items.content_html:
Summary

Removal of mozGetAsFile references.

Motivation

Reponse to issue #16152.

Get rid of HTMLCanvasElement::mozGetAsFile - this was 'removed' (put behind a flag) in 74, it has now been deleted across desktop & mobile. We can delete this page https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLCanvasElement/mozGetAsFile and also the reference here https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLCanvasElement#obsolete_methods

Related issues

#16152

items.content_html:
Replaces class for loop with for...of.

Motivation

The classical for loop would work in more browsers, but is harder to read. When I read the example, I also wondered why it started from the end of the list instead of the beginning, which added a layer of confusion.

Supporting details

I don't have any, but I would like

  • the NamedNodeMap document to say something about how/why for...of works for this interface. Maybe it could say that it implements Symbol.iterator and thus indicate that Element.attributes can/should use for..of?
  • some document that says something along the lines of "for...of is more modern" than classic for loops?

Relevant Links

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/for...of
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/attributes
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/NamedNodeMap

Related issues

N/A

  • Adds a new document

items.content_html:
https://drafts.csswg.org/css-text-decor/#text-decoration-property

text-decoration-thickness is not part of the shorthand.
including it will make the declaration fail in safari.

Also, blink is deprecated as a text-decoration-style, and since it renders as none in most browsers, killed it as an example.

Summary

Motivation

Supporting details

items.title: removed text-decoration-thickness from shorthand

items.content_html:
Summary

The remark made it seem like Object.assign({}, objectWithSetters) copies property descriptors. That is not true and thus the real reason setters are not involved is because the object is never mutated. The next example after this that references Object.assign is also kind of strange but decided not to touch it.

Motivation

the comment made me worry that changing spread syntax from being transpiled to Object.assign to native spread can cause behavioral changes, which it cannot.

Supporting details

Related issues

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Remove misleading statement about setters

items.content_html:
FF101 delivers the Prioritized Task Scheduling API (a prototype) in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1734997

This contains API docs.

Status:

  • Framework docs pretty much done except for examples in them.
  • Next step is create an example, add examples in the top level guide and each page.
  • Update the API concepts and usage.
  • Spellcheck. I seem to have a problem with spelling priority.

Other docs work can be tracked in #15468

items.content_html:
@dipikabh , @teoli2003 , here's an attempt to update the meta-docs to be more prescriptive about examples.

In particular, I want to:

  • require a descriptive heading for each example
  • require a consistent organization for live samples

I removed the bit about linking to examples that live elsewhere, but maybe should put it back as it is probably legitimate sometimes. But I'm not sure how to work that into this structure. An H3 ### More examples? But what if there are only examples that live elsewhere?

Maybe:

  • if there are only linked examples, put them right under ## Examples, with no H3s
  • if there are some in-page examples and some linked ones, put the linked ones last, under an H3 ### More examples

?
items.title: More guidance about examples

items.content_html: This PR adds a .nvmrc file to suggest NodeJS v16 to NVM. This will allow those who use nvm to type nvm use and quickly switch to NodeJS v16 for the project, or automatically switch to v16 depending on shell configuration.
items.title: Add .nvmrc

items.content_html:
This removes an inaccurate description of an example from the Registration section of the web-based protocol handlers reference page.

Summary

Removes a sentence promising something about the example, which is not delivered in the example.

Motivation

The text about the content of the example does not match the content of the example.

Questions

  • I think it would be better to update the example to deliver on the promise, but I was not able to find any existing API for protocol handlers that would allow me to implement such a guard. As such, I've settled on updating the description. However, if anyone knows of an API that would allow us to implement the guard, that would be preferable. Can we update the example instead?
  • If we do have to update the description, it may be worth removing both sentences. I'm not sure how accurate or helpful the remaining sentence: "Registering the same protocol handler more than once will pop up a different notification, indicating that the protocol handler is already registered." For accuracy, I do not have time to test in multiple browsers, but it's not accurate for Chrome. For helpfulness, if I'm right about the web API, there is nothing the developer can do in response to the information, so it doesn't seem extremely relevant. Should this sentence also be deleted?

Supporting details

As noted in the related issue below, the description and example haven't matched since the original commit: https://github.com/mdn/content/blob/main/files/en-us/web/api/navigator/registerprotocolhandler/web-based_protocol_handlers/index.md?plain=1

Related issues

Fixes #15870
